Package absimpa

Class BNF<N,​C extends java.lang.Enum<C>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • absimpa.BNF<N,​C>
  • Type Parameters:
    N - type of node
    C - type of tokencode
    public class BNF<N,​C extends java.lang.Enum<C>>
extends java.lang.Object

    is an alternative to GrammarBuilder to create a grammar by providing a string syntax resembling Backus Naur Form (BNF) to build recursive grammars. The syntax used, as automatically generated with Grammar.toBNF(), is as follows: 

     expr → (product ("[|]" product)*)
 product → term+
 term → (literal oper?)
 literal → ("[A-Za-z][A-Za-z0-9]*" | ("[%]"? "[(]" [expr] "[)]"))
 oper → ("[+]" | "[*]" | "[?]" | ("[{]" range "[}]"))
 range → ("[0-9]+" ("[,]" upperlimit)?)
 upperlimit → ("[0-9]+" | "[*]")

    Tokens are represented by their regular expressions and the brackets in [expr] merely point out that this is a recursive use of the rule expr. The percent sign is used to insert NodeFactory objects in the right place.

    Add rules with rule() and finally compile your start symbol with compile().

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor Description
      BNF​(java.lang.Class<C> enumClass)
      creates a BNF parser and registers all elements c of the enumeration as tokens of the grammar with new TokenGrammar<N,C>(c).

    • Constructor Detail

      • BNF

        public BNF​(java.lang.Class<C> enumClass)

        creates a BNF parser and registers all elements c of the enumeration as tokens of the grammar with new TokenGrammar<N,C>(c). The name of each c is immediately usable in rules.

        Returns:
        the requested grammar or null if the grammar was never defined with an expansion.

      • rule

      • rule

      • rule

        public Grammar<N,​C> rule​(java.lang.String name,
                               java.lang.String expansion,
                               NodeFactory<N> nf)
                        throws ParseException

        translates a rule with the given name into a grammar described by expansion, using the given node factory. An example expansion according to the grammar desribed above is:

         %(term (PLUS term)*)

        This assumes that term is already defined as a rule, at least with rule(String). The same holds for PLUS. Most likely the latter is defined already by the constructor, if PLUS is part of the token code enumeration <C>.

        The node factory provided is inserted at the place of the percent sign. In this example, the node factory would need to be able to combine one or more objects of type N representing term elements into one new N.

        Throws:
        ParseException

      • rule

        public Grammar<N,​C> rule​(java.lang.String name,
                               java.lang.String expansion,
                               NodeFactory<N> nf1,
                               NodeFactory<N> nf2)
                        throws ParseException

        create a rule that uses two node factories.

        Throws:
        ParseException
        See Also:
        rule(String,String,NodeFactory)

      • rule

        public Grammar<N,​C> rule​(java.lang.String name,
                               java.lang.String expansion,
                               NodeFactory<N> nf1,

                               NodeFactory<N>... more)

      • compile

        public Parser<N,​C> compile​(java.lang.String ruleNname)

        compiles a previously defined rule. This will typically be the start symbol of your grammar.

        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if there are rules registered with rule(String) that have no expansion yet. You can always circumvent this restriction by using getGrammar() and calling compile on the result. This may, however, throw other exceptions.

      • main

        public static void main​(java.lang.String[] argv)
        prints the grammar employed to parse grammars.
